column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref
#Text=Alkyl tin trichlorides are important precursors for the preparation of stabilizers for polyvinyl chloride.
#Text=The introduction of alkyl groups onto the tin atom can take place in different ways (cf.
#Text=W.
#Text=P.
#Text=Neumann, Die organische Chemie des Zinns, Ferdinand Enke Verlag, Stuttgart, 1967, pages 16 - 35).
#Text=Nevertheless, in most cases a mixture of higher alkylated tin chlorides is obtained.
#Text=This is particularly true for the preparation of alkyl tin chlorides from tin tetrachloride and alkyl aluminum compounds.
#Text=In this case, a mixture of trialkyl tin chloride and tetraalkyl tin is produced.
#Text=The lower alkylation stages are then attainable by so-called comproportionation (loc. cit., pages 41 - 43).
#Text=Alkyl tin trichloride is obtained, for example, by comproportionation of tetraalkyl tin with tin tetrachloride:
#Text=R.sub.4 Sn + 3SnCl.sub.4 .fwdarw. 4 RSnCl.sub.3.

#Text=The preparation of alkyl tin trihalides according to this process is, however, limited to a few alkyl groups (for example the vinyl group) and occurs only in a special solvent (POCl.sub.3 /P.sub.2 O.sub.5).
#Text=The reason for this difficulty is that the step necessary for complete comproportionation,
#Text=R.sub.2 SnCl.sub.2 + SnCl.sub.4 .fwdarw. 2 RSnCl.sub.3,
#Text=can be realized only in exceptional cases.
#Text=Nevertheless, methods have been developed according to which alkyl tin trichloride is formed in addition to dialkyl tin- or trialkyl tin chlorides (cf.
#Text=German Pat.
#Text=No. 1,161,893 or British Pat.
